groundTruth.text: AbstractSoil moisture is critical to agricultural business, ecosystem health, and certain hydrologically driven natural disasters. Monitoring data, though, is prone to instrumental noise, wide ranging extrema, and nonstationary response to rainfall where ground conditions change. Furthermore, existing soil moisture models generally forecast poorly for time periods greater than a few hours. To improve such forecasts, we introduce two data-driven models, the Naive Accumulative Representation (NAR) and the Additive Exponential Accumulative Representation (AEAR). Both of these models are rooted in deterministic, physically based hydrology, and we study their capabilities in forecasting soil moisture over time periods longer than a few hours. Learned model parameters represent the physically based unsaturated hydrological redistribution processes of gravity and suction. We validate our models using soil moisture and rainfall time series data collected from a steep gradient, post-wildfire site in southern California. Data analysis is complicated by rapid landscape change observed in steep, burned hillslopes in response to even small to moderate rain events. The proposed NAR and AEAR models are, in forecasting experiments, shown to be competitive with several established and state-of-the-art baselines. The AEAR model fits the data well for three distinct soil textures at variable depths below the ground surface (5, 15, and 30 cm). Similar robust results are demonstrated in controlled, laboratory-based experiments. Our AEAR model includes readily interpretable hydrologic parameters and provides more accurate forecasts than existing models for time horizons of 10–24 h. Such extended periods of warning for natural disasters, such as floods and landslides, provide actionable knowledge to reduce loss of life and property.

problem.title: Improving Long-Term Soil Moisture Forecasting Under Nonstationary Environmental Conditions
problem.description: Developing robust, physically interpretable models capable of accurately forecasting soil moisture over extended time horizons (e.g., 10–24 hours) in dynamic, nonstationary environments where ground conditions (e.g., post-wildfire landscapes) and hydrological responses to rainfall are highly variable. The challenge lies in balancing deterministic physical principles with data-driven adaptability to account for instrumental noise, extreme values, and rapid landscape changes.

title.original: AbstractSoil moisture is critical to agricultural business, ecosystem health, and certain hydrologically driven natural disasters. Monitoring data, though, is prone to instrumental noise, wide ranging extrema, and nonstationary response to rainfall where ground conditions change. Furthermore, existing soil moisture models generally forecast poorly for time periods greater than a few hours. To improve such forecasts, we introduce two data-driven models, the Naive Accumulative Representation (NAR) and the Additive Exponential Accumulative Representation (AEAR). Both of these models are rooted in deterministic, physically based hydrology, and we study their capabilities in forecasting soil moisture over time periods longer than a few hours. We validate our models using soil moisture and rainfall time series data collected from a steep gradient, post-wildfire site in southern California. templateData.title: Technical Framework for Long-Term Soil Moisture Forecasting in Nonstationary Environments
templateData.description: Template for developing and evaluating machine learning models that integrate physical principles with adaptive data-driven approaches to forecast soil moisture under highly variable environmental conditions. Emphasizes technical implementation, quantitative metrics, and domain-specific configurations for reproducibility and cross-domain adaptability.

templateProperty.label: Primary Dataset
templateProperty.description: Named dataset(s) used for training/validation, including in-situ soil moisture sensors, satellite observations (e.g., SMAP, Sentinel-1), and meteorological forcings (e.g., ERA5, GFS). Specify spatial/temporal resolution.

templateProperty.label: Data Collection Period
templateProperty.description: Start and end dates of the dataset(s) used (YYYY-MM-DD format). Critical for assessing nonstationarity and temporal generalizability.

templateProperty.label: Spatial Resolution
templateProperty.description: Grid resolution of input data (e.g., 9 km for SMAP, 1 km for Sentinel-1) in meters. Affects model’s ability to capture local variability.

templateProperty.label: Temporal Resolution
templateProperty.description: Time step of input data (e.g., hourly, 3-hourly) in hours. Determines forecast horizon granularity.

templateProperty.label: Preprocessing Steps
templateProperty.description: Technical pipeline for handling missing data, noise (e.g., RFI in SMAP), and extreme values (e.g., post-wildfire spikes). Include normalization (e.g., min-max, log-transform), gap-filling (e.g., linear interpolation, GANs), and alignment of multi-source data.

templateProperty.label: Model Architecture
templateProperty.description: Named architecture (e.g., Physics-Guided RNN, Transformer, Hybrid CNN-LSTM) or custom design. Specify if it includes physical constraints (e.g., mass conservation) or attention mechanisms for temporal dynamics.

templateProperty.label: Physical Constraints
templateProperty.description: Equations or principles embedded in the model (e.g., Richards equation for soil water flow, energy balance). Describe how they are integrated (e.g., loss function regularization, hard constraints).

templateProperty.label: Data-Driven to Physical Ratio
templateProperty.description: Percentage of model parameters that are learned vs. physically fixed (e.g., 70% data-driven, 30% physical). Quantifies the balance between adaptability and interpretability.

templateProperty.label: Training Configuration
templateProperty.description: Hyperparameters and technical setup: optimizer (e.g., AdamW), learning rate (e.g., 1e-4), batch size, early stopping criteria, and hardware (e.g., A100 GPU). Include transfer learning details if applicable.

templateProperty.label: Forecast Horizon
templateProperty.description: Maximum prediction window (e.g., 24 hours) in hours. Must align with temporal resolution and evaluation metrics.

templateProperty.label: Primary Evaluation Metrics
templateProperty.description: Named metrics (e.g., RMSE, NSE, KGE, R²) with justification for nonstationary conditions. Specify if weighted for extreme events (e.g., post-wildfire).

templateProperty.label: RMSE (Root Mean Square Error)
templateProperty.description: Reported RMSE for the forecast horizon (same units as soil moisture, e.g., m³/m³). Critical for assessing error magnitude in dynamic environments.

templateProperty.label: NSE (Nash-Sutcliffe Efficiency)
templateProperty.description: NSE score for the forecast horizon (unitless). Values > 0.5 indicate satisfactory performance; < 0 implies worse than mean baseline.

templateProperty.label: Extreme Event Performance
templateProperty.description: Quantitative comparison of metrics (e.g., RMSE, bias) during extreme conditions (e.g., post-wildfire, heavy rainfall) vs. baseline. Use relative percentages or absolute differences.

templateProperty.label: Adaptability Mechanism
templateProperty.description: Technical method for handling nonstationarity (e.g., online learning, dynamic weight adjustment, ensemble of static/dynamic models). Include trigger conditions (e.g., drift detection).

templateProperty.label: Benchmark Models
templateProperty.description: Named baseline models (e.g., Persistence, ARMA, Physics-Based Only) used for comparison. Specify if they are static or adaptive.

templateProperty.label: Computational Cost
templateProperty.description: Training/inference time per sample (e.g., 0.5s/sample on A100) and memory footprint (e.g., 8GB GPU memory). Critical for operational deployment.

templateProperty.label: Uncertainty Quantification
templateProperty.description: Method for estimating prediction uncertainty (e.g., Bayesian NN, Monte Carlo dropout, ensemble spread). Report if uncertainty correlates with nonstationary periods.

templateProperty.label: Deployment Readiness Level
templateProperty.description: Scale from 1 (theoretical) to 9 (operational) based on TRL (Technology Readiness Level) criteria. Justify with reference to robustness testing and real-world validation.

templateProperty.label: Source Code Repository
templateProperty.description: Link to version-controlled repository with implementation (e.g., GitHub, GitLab). Must include license and documentation for reproducibility.

templateProperty.label: Paper DOI
templateProperty.description: Digital Object Identifier (DOI) for the published work. Ensures citability and access to methodological details.
